Exaggerate: The claim on Facebook exaggerates the announcement that Myanmar will acquire Covid-19 medication and vaccine before the end of 2020. The expert's verdict clarifies that there is no specific mention of a vaccine in the original post, and the newspaper's post did not mention the acquisition of a vaccine.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as the expert's verdict mentions that there is no official announcement or confirmation from the World Health Organization (WHO) regarding the availability of a Covid-19 vaccine in Myanmar.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Myanmar will have official Covid-19 medication and vaccine by the end of 2020 based on a Facebook post and references to Aung San Suu Kyi's speech. However, the expert's verdict clarifies that there is no concrete evidence or official announcement supporting this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by mentioning that the medication referred to in the Facebook post is Remdesivir, which is currently used for severely ill Covid-19 patients. This contradicts the claim that Myanmar will acquire a Covid-19 medication and vaccine.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that as of October 14, 2020, the WHO has not announced the approval or mass production of a Covid-19 vaccine. This contradicts the claim made in the Facebook post.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times in the provided information.
